g.data-desc: Client sends a PROPFIND request to /{username}/{calendar_id}/ to discover properties of a calendar collection. This is the primary mechanism CalDAV clients use to read calendar metadata and enumerate calendar objects. The Depth header controls whether only the calendar itself or also its child objects are returned.

Check the HTTP method of the incoming request. OPTIONS requests return DAV compliance headers immediately without authentication. All other methods (PROPFIND in this flow) continue to the authentication step.
Responds with DAV compliance and allowed method headers so the client knows this is a CalDAV-capable server. No authentication is required for OPTIONS requests.

Authenticates the request using HTTP Basic Auth if credentials are provided, verifying the password with Argon2id. Falls back to resolving the user from the URL path if no credentials are sent. The path fallback exists because Apple Calendar does not send credentials to /caldav/users/* URLs.

Checks whether a valid user was identified through credentials or the URL path. If yes, the authenticated user is available for subsequent authorization checks. If no, the request is rejected as unauthorized.

No valid user could be identified from the request. The response prompts the client to provide Basic Auth credentials. The same error is returned for invalid credentials and unknown usernames to prevent enumeration.

Verifies that the authenticated user has access to this calendar collection. The user must be either the calendar owner or have been granted shared access. If the user has no access, the request is denied with 403 Forbidden.

The authenticated user does not have access to this calendar. The calendar may belong to another user and has not been shared. Returns 403 rather than 404 to avoid leaking calendar existence information.

Reads the XML request body to determine which properties the client is requesting. Also extracts the Depth header, which controls whether only the calendar collection itself (Depth 0) or also its child objects (Depth 1) are returned. If no body is provided, all available properties are included.
g.text: Extract requested props and Depth header

g.data-desc: Looks up the calendar by its ID from the URL path and checks whether it exists in the database. If the calendar does not exist, the request fails with 404 Not Found. If it exists, the server proceeds to build the response.
No calendar with the requested ID exists in the database. The client may have an outdated calendar reference or a typo in the URL.

Constructs a 207 Multi-Status XML response containing the calendar collection's properties. Includes properties like displayname, calendar-color, ctag, supported-component-set, getetag, and resourcetype. Only properties requested by the client are included; unknown properties go in a 404 propstat.

Checks whether the client requested child resources via the Depth header. Depth 0 means only the calendar collection itself is returned. Depth 1 means the server must also include all calendar objects (events) within the collection.

Returns the multistatus response containing only the calendar collection's own properties. No child objects are included because the client requested Depth 0. The response includes a single DAV response element for the calendar itself.

Queries all calendar objects belonging to this calendar collection from the database. Each object is added to the multistatus response as a separate DAV response element, including its href, getetag, content-type, and optionally the full calendar-data. This allows clients to discover all events in a single request.

Returns the complete multistatus response containing the calendar collection properties and all of its calendar objects. Each object includes its href, getetag, and content-type. If the client requested calendar-data, the full iCalendar payload is included inline.
End of PROPFIND request processing for the calendar collection level.
